SEARCH
Package controller

Class Controller

java.lang.Object
controller.Controller
public class Controller extends Object
Central controller class serving as the main coordinator for the airport management system.

This class implements the facade pattern to provide a unified interface for managing all system operations and serves as the primary integration point between the GUI layer, business logic, and data access layers. It coordinates operations across multiple specialized controllers and maintains system-wide state and logging.

The Controller is responsible for:

  • Coordinating operations between specialized controllers (Admin, Booking, Customer, etc.)
  • Managing navigation and window lifecycle through DisposableObject chains
  • Handling complex business operations that span multiple domains
  • Providing centralized logging and error handling capabilities
  • Managing user authentication and session state across the application
  • Coordinating database operations for complex multi-table transactions

The class maintains instances of all specialized controllers, providing access to their functionality while orchestrating interactions between them. This design ensures loose coupling between GUI components and business logic while maintaining centralized control over system operations.

Navigation management includes sophisticated window state preservation, allowing users to navigate back through the application hierarchy while maintaining window size, position, and state information. This provides a consistent and intuitive user experience across all application interfaces.

The controller integrates extensively with the database layer through various DAO implementations, coordinating complex operations such as booking creation, flight management, and passenger processing that require interactions with multiple database tables while maintaining data consistency and integrity.

Error handling and logging are centralized through this controller, providing consistent error reporting and user feedback across all system operations. The logging system supports operational monitoring and debugging for system maintenance and troubleshooting.

Since:
1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • Controller

      public Controller()
      Constructs a new Controller instance and initializes all specialized controllers.

      This constructor creates instances of all specialized controllers that manage different aspects of the airport management system. Each controller is initialized with default state and is ready to handle operations within its domain.

      The initialization follows a dependency-free approach where controllers are created independently and coordinate through this central controller rather than having direct dependencies on each other.

      All controllers are created as final instances to ensure immutability of the controller architecture and prevent accidental reassignment during system operation.

  • Method Details

    • getBookingController

      public BookingController getBookingController()
      Retrieves the booking controller instance for booking-related operations.

      This method provides access to the BookingController which manages all booking-related operations including creation, modification, deletion, and search functionality. The controller maintains booking session state and coordinates with passenger and luggage management.

      The booking controller is used throughout the application for reservation management, customer service operations, and administrative booking oversight functions.

      Returns:
      the BookingController instance for booking operations

    • getCustomerController

      public CustomerController getCustomerController()
      Retrieves the customer controller instance for customer-related operations.

      This method provides access to the CustomerController which manages customer authentication, session state, profile information, and customer-specific operations throughout the system.

      The customer controller is essential for customer login workflows, booking management, profile updates, and customer service operations that require customer context and authorization.

      Returns:
      the CustomerController instance for customer operations

    • getFlightController

      public FlightController getFlightController()
      Retrieves the flight controller instance for flight-related operations.

      This method provides access to the FlightController which manages all flight-related operations including flight information, scheduling, passenger management, check-in procedures, and flight status updates.

      The flight controller is central to most system operations as it provides the context for bookings, tickets, passengers, and operational procedures across both customer and administrative interfaces.

      Returns:
      the FlightController instance for flight operations

    • getGateController

      public GateController getGateController()
      Retrieves the gate controller instance for gate management operations.

      This method provides access to the GateController which manages gate assignments, availability checking, and integration with flight check-in procedures and operational workflows.

      The gate controller is used during administrative operations, flight check-in procedures, and operational management where gate assignments need to be managed or verified.

      Returns:
      the GateController instance for gate operations

    • getLuggageController

      public LuggageController getLuggageController()
      Retrieves the luggage controller instance for luggage management operations.

      This method provides access to the LuggageController which manages luggage search results, status tracking, lost luggage reporting, and administrative luggage management functions.

      The luggage controller is essential for customer service operations, administrative luggage management, and lost luggage recovery workflows that require luggage information and status management.

      Returns:
      the LuggageController instance for luggage operations

    • getUserController

      public UserController getUserController()
      Retrieves the user controller instance for user management operations.

      This method provides access to the UserController which manages user authentication, session state, input validation, account registration, and account deletion for both administrators and customers.

      The user controller provides unified user management capabilities that work across both administrator and customer user types, handling common operations such as login, profile management, and account operations.

      Returns:
      the UserController instance for user operations

    • goToLogin

      public void goToLogin(List<DisposableObject> callingObjects)
      Navigates to the login screen and clears the application stack.

      This method implements navigation to the login screen by disposing of all windows in the calling objects stack except the first one (login screen), then restoring the login window with preserved size, position, and state information from the current window.

      The navigation process includes:

      • Capturing current window state (size, position, maximization)
      • Disposing all windows from the stack except the login window
      • Calling disposal handlers for proper cleanup
      • Restoring window state to the login window
      • Calling restoration handlers for proper initialization
      • Making the login window visible

      Window state preservation ensures that the login screen appears with the same size, position, and maximization state as the window from which the navigation was initiated, providing visual continuity for the user.

      This method is typically called during logout operations, session expiration, or when authentication is required for protected operations.

      Parameters:
      callingObjects - the stack of DisposableObject windows representing the navigation hierarchy

    • goHome

      public void goHome(List<DisposableObject> callingObjects)
      Navigates to the home screen and clears intermediate windows.

      This method implements navigation to the home screen by disposing of all windows in the calling objects stack except the first two (login and home), then restoring the home window with preserved size, position, and state information from the current window.

      The navigation process follows the same pattern as goToLogin(List) but preserves both the login window (index 0) and home window (index 1) in the navigation stack, disposing only windows at index 2 and higher.

      This method is typically called when users want to return to the main application interface from deep navigation paths, providing a quick way to return to the primary functionality without losing the login context.

      Window state preservation ensures visual continuity by maintaining the size, position, and maximization state from the current window when displaying the home screen.

      Parameters:
      callingObjects - the stack of DisposableObject windows representing the navigation hierarchy

    • goBack

      public void goBack(List<DisposableObject> callingObjects)
      Navigates back to the previous screen in the navigation hierarchy.

      This method implements standard back navigation by disposing the current window and restoring the previous window in the calling objects stack. It preserves window state information from the current window and applies it to the previous window for visual continuity.

      The back navigation process includes:

      • Capturing current window state (size, position, maximization)
      • Calling disposal handler for the current window
      • Disposing the current window and removing it from the stack
      • Applying captured state to the previous window
      • Calling restoration handler for the previous window
      • Making the previous window visible

      This method provides standard navigation behavior expected in GUI applications, allowing users to navigate back through their action history while maintaining context and visual state.

      The method is typically called by back buttons, escape key handlers, or cancel operations that should return users to the previous interface.

      Parameters:
      callingObjects - the stack of DisposableObject windows representing the navigation hierarchy

    • logOut

      public void logOut(List<DisposableObject> callingObjects)
      Performs user logout by clearing all application windows except the login screen.

      This method implements complete logout functionality by disposing all application windows except the login screen, effectively clearing the user session and returning to the authentication interface. Unlike other navigation methods, this method does not preserve window state since logout represents a session termination.

      The logout process includes:

      • Disposing all windows except the login window (index 0)
      • Calling disposal handlers for proper cleanup
      • Removing all windows from the navigation stack except login
      • Calling restoration handler for the login window
      • Making the login window visible

      This method effectively terminates the user session by clearing all application state and returning to the initial authentication state. The login window is restored to its default state without preserving window dimensions or position from the logout context.

      The method is typically called by logout buttons, session timeout handlers, or security-related operations that require user reauthentication.

      Note: This method only handles UI navigation and window management. Actual session data cleanup (user information, cached data, etc.) should be handled separately through appropriate controller methods.

      Parameters:
      callingObjects - the stack of DisposableObject windows representing the navigation hierarchy

    • addBooking

      public void addBooking(List<PassengerPanel> passengerPanels, String bookingStatus)
      Creates a new booking with passenger information and specified status.

      This method handles the complete booking creation process by extracting passenger information from GUI panels, preparing the data for database insertion, and coordinating with the BookingDAOImpl to persist the booking with all associated tickets, passengers, and luggage information.

      The booking creation process includes:

      • Extracting passenger details from PassengerPanel components
      • Generating unique ticket numbers for each passenger
      • Processing seat assignments and passenger personal information
      • Handling luggage associations with tickets
      • Database persistence through the DAO layer

      The method delegates data preparation to preparePassengers(List, List, List, List, List, List, List, List, List) which processes all passenger panels and extracts the necessary information for database operations. This includes ticket number generation, seat assignments, personal details, and luggage type associations.

      Database operations are performed atomically to ensure data consistency across multiple tables including bookings, tickets, passengers, and luggage records. The booking is associated with the currently logged-in user and the selected flight.

      Error handling includes comprehensive exception catching with appropriate logging for system monitoring and debugging. Database errors are logged at SEVERE level for operational oversight and troubleshooting purposes.

      The method is typically called from booking confirmation interfaces where customers have completed passenger information entry and are ready to finalize their reservation.

      Parameters:
      passengerPanels - list of PassengerPanel objects containing passenger information and preferences
      bookingStatus - the initial status for the booking (e.g., "CONFIRMED", "PENDING")

    • translateFlightStatus

      public static String translateFlightStatus(FlightStatus status)
      Translates flight status enumeration values to localized Italian strings.

      This static utility method provides consistent translation of FlightStatus enumeration values to user-friendly Italian text for display in the user interface. It ensures that flight status information is presented in a language appropriate for the target user base.

      The translation mapping includes all standard flight status values:

      • PROGRAMMED: "In programma" (Scheduled)
      • CANCELLED: "Cancellato" (Cancelled)
      • DELAYED: "In ritardo" (Delayed)
      • ABOUT_TO_DEPART: "In partenza" (About to depart)
      • DEPARTED: "Partito" (Departed)
      • ABOUT_TO_ARRIVE: "In arrivo" (About to arrive)
      • LANDED: "Atterrato" (Landed)

      The method is designed to be extensible, returning null for unrecognized status values to enable graceful handling of new status types that may be added to the system in future versions.

      This centralized translation approach ensures consistency across all user interface components and enables easy maintenance of localization strings throughout the application.

      Parameters:
      status - the FlightStatus enumeration value to translate
      Returns:
      the Italian translation of the flight status, or null if the status is not recognized

    • modifyBooking

      public void modifyBooking(List<PassengerPanel> passengerPanels, String bookingStatus)
      Modifies an existing booking with updated passenger information and status.

      This method handles the complete booking modification process by extracting updated passenger information from GUI panels, preparing the data for database updates, and coordinating with the BookingDAOImpl to persist changes to the booking and all associated records.

      The booking modification process includes:

      • Extracting updated passenger details from PassengerPanel components
      • Preserving existing ticket numbers where possible
      • Generating new ticket numbers for additional passengers
      • Processing updated seat assignments and personal information
      • Handling luggage modifications and associations
      • Database updates through the DAO layer

      The method uses the same data preparation logic as booking creation through preparePassengers(List, List, List, List, List, List, List, List, List) but operates in modification mode where existing booking and flight contexts are maintained.

      Database operations include updating existing records and potentially creating new tickets for additional passengers while maintaining referential integrity across all related tables. The modification preserves the original booking creation date and customer association.

      The method generates additional ticket numbers as needed using generateTicketNumber(int) with appropriate offset values to ensure uniqueness within the booking context.

      Error handling includes comprehensive exception catching with appropriate logging for system monitoring. Database errors are logged at SEVERE level for operational oversight and troubleshooting purposes.

      The method is typically called from booking modification interfaces where customers or administrators have updated passenger information and are ready to save the changes to the reservation.

      Parameters:
      passengerPanels - list of PassengerPanel objects containing updated passenger information
      bookingStatus - the updated status for the booking (e.g., "CONFIRMED", "PENDING", "CANCELLED")

    • generateTicketNumber

      public String generateTicketNumber(int offset)
      Generates a unique ticket number with an offset for numbering consistency.

      This method delegates ticket number generation to the TicketDAOImpl which implements the actual generation logic based on system requirements and database constraints. The offset parameter enables consistent numbering within booking contexts where multiple tickets need sequential identification.

      Ticket numbers are typically alphanumeric strings that serve as unique identifiers throughout the system and are used for passenger identification, check-in procedures, and customer service operations.

      The offset mechanism enables predictable numbering patterns within bookings while maintaining global uniqueness across the entire system. This is particularly useful for group bookings where tickets need to be numbered sequentially for organizational purposes.

      The method provides a clean interface between the controller logic and the database-specific ticket number generation algorithms, enabling changes to the generation strategy without affecting calling code.

      Parameters:
      offset - the numerical offset to apply during ticket number generation
      Returns:
      a unique ticket number string incorporating the specified offset

    • setErrorButton

      public void setErrorButton(JButton errorButton)
      Sets the reference button for displaying system-wide error messages.

      This method establishes a UI button reference that can be used as a fallback for displaying error messages when operations don't have a specific UI context but still need to provide user feedback. This is particularly useful for background operations or system-level errors.

      The error button serves as an anchor point for FloatingMessage components that need to display error information in cases where the original operation context may not be available or appropriate.

      This centralized error display mechanism ensures that users receive appropriate feedback for all system operations, even those that occur outside of specific user interface workflows.

      Parameters:
      errorButton - the JButton to use as a reference for error message display

    • getAllBooksLoogedCustomer

      public void getAllBooksLoogedCustomer(List<Date> bookingDates, List<String> bookingStatus, List<String> flightIds, JButton searchButton)
      Retrieves all bookings for the currently logged-in customer with comprehensive flight information.

      This method performs a comprehensive search for all bookings associated with the currently logged-in customer, retrieving complete flight information, passenger details, and organizing the data into synchronized collections for display and processing purposes.

      The operation involves multiple complex processes:

      • Database query through BookingDAOImpl to retrieve customer bookings
      • Flight object creation based on flight type (Departing/Arriving)
      • Ticket information retrieval for each booking
      • Complete booking object construction with all associations
      • Passenger data organization and deduplication
      • Search result population across multiple controllers

      The method handles flight type determination by creating appropriate Departing or Arriving flight objects based on database type indicators. This ensures that flight-specific behavior and information display is handled correctly throughout the application.

      Ticket processing includes retrieving all tickets associated with each booking and constructing complete Ticket objects with passenger associations. The method handles both single and multi-passenger bookings, ensuring that all ticket relationships are properly established.

      Data deduplication logic prevents duplicate entries in search results while maintaining proper relationships between bookings, tickets, passengers, and flights. This includes SSN-based passenger deduplication and flight ID-based flight deduplication.

      The method populates search results across multiple specialized controllers (BookingController, FlightController, TicketController, PassengerController) to enable comprehensive data access from different application components.

      Error handling includes comprehensive exception catching with user-friendly error messages displayed through FloatingMessage components. Database connectivity issues are handled gracefully with appropriate user feedback.

      The method is typically called when users access their booking history or when the system needs to display comprehensive customer booking information for administrative or customer service purposes.

      Parameters:
      bookingDates - list to be populated with booking creation dates
      bookingStatus - list to be populated with current booking status values
      flightIds - list to be populated with flight identifiers associated with bookings
      searchButton - UI button reference for displaying error messages if operations fail

    • searchBooksLoogedCustomerFilteredFlights

      public void searchBooksLoogedCustomerFilteredFlights(String origin, String destination, LocalDate dateBefore, LocalDate dateAfter, LocalTime timeBefore, LocalTime timeAfter, List<Date> bookingDates, List<String> bookingStatus, List<String> flightIds, JButton searchButton)
      Searches customer bookings with flight-based filtering criteria and comprehensive data retrieval.

      This method performs an advanced search for bookings belonging to the currently logged-in customer using flight-specific filtering criteria such as origin, destination, dates, and times. It retrieves complete booking information including flight details, passenger data, and organizes the results for display and processing.

      The filtering capabilities include:

      • Geographic filtering: Origin and destination city matching
      • Temporal filtering: Date range and time window constraints
      • Customer-specific results: Limited to current user's bookings
      • Comprehensive data retrieval: Complete flight and passenger information

      The method follows the same comprehensive data processing pattern as getAllBooksLoogedCustomer(List, List, List, JButton) but applies additional filtering constraints through the BookingDAO.searchBooksCustomerFilteredFlights(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.time.LocalDate, java.time.LocalDate, java.time.LocalTime, java.time.LocalTime, java.lang.Integer, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.sql.Date>, java.util.List<java.sql.Time>, java.util.List<java.sql.Time>, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.lang.Boolean>, java.util.List<java.sql.Date>, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>) method to limit results to flights matching the specified criteria.

      Database operations include complex filtering queries that join multiple tables to provide flight information, booking details, and passenger data while maintaining performance through optimized query structures and appropriate database indexing strategies.

      The method creates appropriate flight objects (Departing or Arriving) based on flight type indicators, ensuring that flight-specific behavior and information presentation is handled correctly throughout the application.

      Ticket and passenger processing includes complete object construction with proper associations, deduplication logic to prevent duplicate entries, and organization into search result collections across multiple specialized controllers.

      The search results are populated across multiple controllers to enable comprehensive data access from different application components, maintaining the same data structure and relationships as non-filtered searches.

      Error handling includes comprehensive exception catching with user-friendly error messages displayed through FloatingMessage components. Database connectivity issues and query failures are handled gracefully with appropriate user feedback.

      The method is typically called from search interfaces where customers can filter their booking history based on flight characteristics, enabling efficient retrieval of specific bookings from potentially large booking histories.

      Parameters:
      origin - the origin city name for filtering (null or empty for no filter)
      destination - the destination city name for filtering (null or empty for no filter)
      dateBefore - the earliest date for filtering (null for no lower bound)
      dateAfter - the latest date for filtering (null for no upper bound)
      timeBefore - the earliest time for filtering (null for no lower bound)
      timeAfter - the latest time for filtering (null for no upper bound)
      bookingDates - list to be populated with booking creation dates from filtered results
      bookingStatus - list to be populated with booking status values from filtered results
      flightIds - list to be populated with flight identifiers from filtered results
      searchButton - UI button reference for displaying error messages if operations fail

    • searchBooksLoogedCustomerFilteredPassengers

      public void searchBooksLoogedCustomerFilteredPassengers(String firstName, String lastName, String passengerSSN, String ticketNumber, List<Date> bookingDates, List<String> bookingStatus, List<String> flightIds, JButton searchButton)
      Searches customer bookings with passenger-based filtering criteria and comprehensive data retrieval.

      This method performs an advanced search for bookings belonging to the currently logged-in customer using passenger-specific filtering criteria such as first name, last name, SSN, and ticket number. It retrieves complete booking information including flight details, passenger data, and organizes the results for display and processing.

      The filtering capabilities include:

      • Personal information filtering: First name and last name matching
      • Identity filtering: SSN (Social Security Number) matching
      • Ticket-specific filtering: Exact ticket number matching
      • Customer-specific results: Limited to current user's bookings
      • Comprehensive data retrieval: Complete flight and passenger information

      The method follows the same comprehensive data processing pattern as other booking search methods but applies passenger-specific filtering constraints through the BookingDAO.searchBooksCustomerFilteredPassengers(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.lang.String, java.lang.Integer, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.sql.Date>, java.util.List<java.sql.Time>, java.util.List<java.sql.Time>, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.lang.Boolean>, java.util.List<java.sql.Date>, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>) method to limit results to bookings containing passengers matching the specified criteria.

      Database operations include complex filtering queries that join multiple tables (bookings, passengers, tickets, flights) to provide comprehensive information while maintaining performance through optimized query structures and appropriate database indexing strategies.

      The method creates appropriate flight objects (Departing or Arriving) based on flight type indicators, ensuring that flight-specific behavior and information presentation is handled correctly throughout the application.

      Ticket and passenger processing includes complete object construction with proper associations, deduplication logic to prevent duplicate entries, and organization into search result collections across multiple specialized controllers.

      The search results are populated across multiple controllers (BookingController, FlightController, TicketController, PassengerController) to enable comprehensive data access from different application components, maintaining the same data structure and relationships as other search operations.

      Error handling includes comprehensive exception catching with user-friendly error messages displayed through FloatingMessage components. Database connectivity issues and query failures are handled gracefully with appropriate user feedback.

      The method is typically called from search interfaces where customers can filter their booking history based on passenger characteristics, enabling efficient retrieval of specific bookings from potentially large booking histories. This is particularly useful for customers with multiple bookings or group travelers.

      Parameters:
      firstName - the first name for filtering (null or empty for no filter)
      lastName - the last name for filtering (null or empty for no filter)
      passengerSSN - the passenger SSN for filtering (null or empty for no filter)
      ticketNumber - the ticket number for exact matching (null or empty for no filter)
      bookingDates - list to be populated with booking creation dates from filtered results
      bookingStatus - list to be populated with booking status values from filtered results
      flightIds - list to be populated with flight identifiers from filtered results
      searchButton - UI button reference for displaying error messages if operations fail

    • loadAndCheckIfOpenMyBookingsOrNewBooking

      public boolean loadAndCheckIfOpenMyBookingsOrNewBooking()
      Loads and checks if existing customer bookings should open booking management or new booking creation.

      This method performs a specialized search to determine whether the currently logged-in customer has existing bookings for the currently selected flight. It retrieves all customer bookings for the specific flight and populates the search result collections to enable either booking modification workflows or new booking creation processes.

      The method serves dual purposes in the booking workflow:

      • Existing Booking Detection: Identifies if customer has bookings for the current flight
      • Data Population: Loads complete booking information for modification workflows
      • Workflow Direction: Determines whether to show modification or creation interfaces
      • Session Preparation: Prepares controller states for subsequent operations

      The operation involves several key processes:

      • Database query through BookingDAO.searchBooksCustomerForAFlight(java.lang.String, java.lang.Integer, java.util.List<java.sql.Date>, java.util.List<java.lang.String>, java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>) for flight-specific bookings
      • Flight information preparation with current flight context
      • Complete ticket information retrieval for each booking
      • Booking object construction with full passenger associations
      • Passenger data organization and deduplication
      • Search result population across multiple controllers

      The method initializes search result collections across multiple specialized controllers (FlightController, BookingController, TicketController, PassengerController) to ensure that subsequent booking operations have access to complete and properly organized data structures.

      Flight context is established by adding the current flight to the flight controller's search results, providing the necessary context for booking operations that require flight information integration.

      Ticket processing includes retrieving all tickets associated with each booking and constructing complete Ticket objects with passenger associations. The method handles both single and multi-passenger bookings, ensuring that all ticket relationships are properly established.

      Data deduplication logic prevents duplicate passenger entries in search results while maintaining proper relationships between bookings, tickets, and passengers. This includes SSN-based passenger deduplication to ensure data consistency.

      Error handling includes comprehensive exception catching with user-friendly error messages displayed through FloatingMessage components using the error button reference. Database connectivity issues are handled gracefully with appropriate feedback.

      The method is typically called during flight selection workflows where the system needs to determine whether to present existing booking modification interfaces or new booking creation forms to the customer.

      Returns:
      true if the customer has existing bookings for the current flight, false if no bookings exist

    • clearSearchBookingResultCache

      public void clearSearchBookingResultCache()
      Clears all cached search result data from booking-related controllers.

      This utility method performs comprehensive cleanup of search result collections across multiple specialized controllers to ensure that stale data does not interfere with new search operations or booking workflows. It resets the search result state to a clean condition for subsequent operations.

      The cleanup process includes:

      • Booking Results: Clears booking objects and their database IDs
      • Flight Results: Clears flight search result collections
      • Session Reset: Ensures clean state for new operations
      • Memory Management: Releases references to potentially large data sets

      Controllers affected by this cleanup include:

      • BookingController - booking search results and corresponding IDs
      • FlightController - flight search result collections

      This method is typically called between different search operations, when switching between different booking contexts, or when preparing for new booking workflows to ensure that previous search results do not interfere with current operations.

      The cleanup is essential for maintaining data integrity across different user sessions and preventing cross-contamination of search results from different operations or user contexts.

      Memory management benefits include releasing references to potentially large collections of booking, flight, and associated objects, helping to optimize application memory usage during extended user sessions.

    • clearSearchFlightsResultCache

      public void clearSearchFlightsResultCache()
      Clears cached flight search result data from the flight controller.

      This utility method performs cleanup of flight search result collections to ensure that stale flight data does not interfere with new search operations or flight selection workflows. It resets the flight search state to a clean condition for subsequent operations.

      The cleanup process includes:

      • Flight Search Results: Clears flight object collections
      • Session Reset: Ensures clean state for new flight searches
      • Memory Management: Releases references to flight data sets
      • Context Clearing: Removes previous search context

      The cleanup specifically targets the FlightController's search result collections, which contain flight objects retrieved from previous search operations. This ensures that new searches start with a clean slate and do not display outdated or irrelevant flight information.

      This method is typically called when:

      • Initiating new flight searches with different criteria
      • Switching between different flight search contexts
      • Preparing for booking operations that require fresh flight data
      • Resetting the application state between user sessions

      Memory management benefits include releasing references to flight objects and their associated collections, which can be significant in systems handling large numbers of flights or extended search sessions.

      The cleanup ensures data integrity by preventing confusion between results from different search operations and maintaining clean separation between different user interaction workflows.

    • verifyUser

      public boolean verifyUser(String loggingInfo, String hashedPassword, JButton loginButton)
      Verifies user credentials and establishes authenticated session for administrators or customers.

      This method performs comprehensive user authentication by validating credentials against both administrator and customer databases, establishing appropriate user sessions upon successful authentication. It supports both email and username-based login with proper input validation and user feedback.

      The authentication process includes:

      • Input Validation: Email format and username format validation
      • Database Queries: Administrator database search followed by customer database search
      • Session Establishment: User object creation and controller state initialization
      • Error Handling: Comprehensive error feedback for various failure scenarios

      Login identifier flexibility supports both email addresses and usernames:

      • Email Login: Identified by presence of '@' character, validated against email format rules
      • Username Login: Standard username format validation and database lookup

      Authentication follows a hierarchical approach:

      1. Administrator Check: First attempts authentication against administrator database
      2. Customer Fallback: If administrator authentication fails, attempts customer authentication
      3. Session Creation: Establishes appropriate user session based on user type

      Session establishment includes:

      • Setting logged user in AdminController or CustomerController
      • Setting unified user session in UserController
      • Storing user database ID for subsequent operations
      • Creating appropriate user objects (Admin or Customer)

      Input validation prevents unnecessary database queries for obviously invalid credentials, improving performance and reducing database load. Validation is performed using the methods from UserController.

      Error handling provides specific user feedback for different failure scenarios:

      • Validation Errors: Invalid email or username format
      • Authentication Errors: Incorrect credentials
      • Database Errors: Connection or query execution problems

      Security considerations include password hashing verification and protection against SQL injection through parameterized queries in the DAO layer.

      The method is typically called from login interfaces where users enter their credentials to access the system. Successful authentication enables access to user-specific functionality and booking operations.

      Parameters:
      loggingInfo - the login identifier (email address or username)
      hashedPassword - the pre-hashed password for authentication
      loginButton - UI button reference for displaying authentication feedback messages
      Returns:
      true if authentication was successful and user session was established, false otherwise

    • setBookedSeats

      public void setBookedSeats(List<Integer> bookedSeats)
      Retrieves and populates booked seat information for the current flight and booking context.

      This method queries the database to retrieve all seats that are currently booked for the active flight, excluding seats from the current booking session. This information is essential for seat selection interfaces to prevent conflicts and ensure that customers can only select available seats.

      The operation involves:

      • Database Query: Retrieval of booked seats through FlightDAOImpl
      • Context Filtering: Exclusion of current booking's seats from the booked list
      • List Population: Direct population of the provided list with seat numbers
      • Session Integration: Uses current flight and booking context

      The method uses the current flight ID from FlightController and the current booking ID from BookingController to ensure that the seat availability information is accurate for the current booking context.

      Seat filtering logic ensures that seats from the current booking session are not included in the booked seats list, allowing customers to re-select their own previously chosen seats during booking modification operations.

      This method is typically called during booking creation or modification workflows where customers need to select seats, and the system must prevent double-booking of seats while allowing flexibility within the current booking session.

      The populated list is used by seat selection components to disable unavailable seats in the user interface, providing clear visual feedback about seat availability and preventing booking conflicts.

      Integration with the flight management system ensures that seat availability information is always current and reflects the real-time state of bookings for the flight.

      Parameters:
      bookedSeats - list to be populated with seat numbers that are currently booked for the flight

    • isLoggedAdmin

      public boolean isLoggedAdmin()
      Determines whether the currently logged-in user is an administrator.

      This method performs runtime type checking on the currently logged-in user to determine their role within the system. It provides a simple boolean interface for role-based access control and feature availability decisions throughout the application.

      The determination process:

      • Type Checking: Uses instanceof operator on the logged user object
      • Role Identification: Distinguishes between Admin and Customer types
      • Session Context: Relies on current user session from UserController
      • Boolean Result: Returns clear true/false for role-based decisions

      This method is essential for:

      • Access Control: Determining access to administrative features
      • UI Customization: Showing or hiding role-specific interface elements
      • Workflow Direction: Routing users to appropriate application sections
      • Permission Validation: Ensuring users can only access authorized functionality

      The method leverages the polymorphic user session design where both administrators and customers are stored as User objects in the UserController, but maintain their specific type information for role determination.

      Usage scenarios include:

      • Determining whether to show administrative menu options
      • Enabling or disabling management features in the interface
      • Routing users to role-appropriate home screens or dashboards
      • Validating permissions before executing administrative operations

      The method assumes that a user session is active and will return false if no user is logged in or if the logged user is not an administrator type. This provides safe default behavior for unauthorized or unauthenticated access.

      Integration with the broader authentication and authorization system ensures that role-based access control is consistently applied across all application components and user interaction workflows.

      Returns:
      true if the currently logged-in user is an administrator, false if the user is a customer or no user is logged in

    • getLostLuggages

      public void getLostLuggages(List<String> flightIds, List<Date> bookingDates, List<String> firstNames, List<String> lastNames, List<String> passengerSSNs, List<String> luggageIdsAfterCheckin)
      Retrieves comprehensive information about all lost luggage items in the system for recovery operations.

      This method performs a complex database operation to fetch complete information about all luggage items that have been reported as lost throughout the airport management system. It provides a comprehensive view of lost luggage including associated flight details, passenger information, booking data, and luggage specifications for recovery and customer service operations.

      The operation involves multiple complex processes:

      • Database query through LuggageDAOImpl to retrieve all lost luggage items
      • Flight object creation based on flight type (Departing/Arriving) for lost luggage context
      • Customer information retrieval for lost luggage owners
      • Complete booking and ticket object construction with all associations
      • Luggage object creation with proper status and type information
      • Search result population across multiple controllers for comprehensive data access

      The method handles flight type determination by creating appropriate Departing or Arriving flight objects based on database type indicators. This ensures that flight-specific behavior and information display is handled correctly for lost luggage recovery operations.

      Customer processing includes creating Customer objects for all luggage owners, enabling customer service representatives to contact affected passengers and coordinate luggage recovery efforts. Customer information is deduplicated to prevent redundant entries while maintaining proper associations.

      Booking and ticket processing includes complete object construction with proper associations, ensuring that lost luggage items can be traced back to their original bookings and associated with the correct passengers. This enables comprehensive luggage recovery workflows.

      Luggage object creation handles both typed luggage (with specific LuggageType) and untyped luggage items, ensuring that all lost luggage is properly represented regardless of the completeness of the original luggage information.

      Data deduplication logic prevents duplicate entries across flights, customers, bookings, tickets, and passengers while maintaining proper relationships between all entities. This includes flight ID-based flight deduplication, customer ID-based customer deduplication, booking ID-based booking deduplication, ticket number-based ticket deduplication, and SSN-based passenger deduplication.

      The method populates search results across multiple specialized controllers (FlightController, CustomerController, BookingController, TicketController, PassengerController, LuggageController) to enable comprehensive data access from different application components for lost luggage recovery operations.

      Error handling includes comprehensive exception catching with user-friendly error messages displayed through FloatingMessage components using the error button reference. Database connectivity issues are handled gracefully with appropriate user feedback and detailed logging for operational oversight.

      The method is typically called by administrative interfaces that need to display comprehensive lost luggage information for recovery operations, customer service inquiries, and operational reporting purposes.

      Integration with the broader luggage management system ensures that lost luggage information is always current and reflects the real-time state of luggage recovery operations throughout the airport system.

      Parameters:
      flightIds - list to be populated with flight identifiers associated with lost luggage
      bookingDates - list to be populated with booking creation dates for lost luggage context
      firstNames - list to be populated with passenger first names for customer contact
      lastNames - list to be populated with passenger last names for customer contact
      passengerSSNs - list to be populated with passenger SSNs for identity verification
      luggageIdsAfterCheckin - list to be populated with physical luggage identifiers for tracking

    • setBookingResultSelectedFlightForLostLuaggages

      public void setBookingResultSelectedFlightForLostLuaggages(Integer luggageIndex)
      Sets the booking result selected flight context for lost luggage recovery operations.

      This method establishes flight context for lost luggage recovery by setting the flight associated with a specific lost luggage item as the current active flight. It also adds the associated booking to the flight's booking collection to provide complete context for luggage recovery operations.

      The operation involves:

      • Retrieving the flight associated with the specified lost luggage item
      • Setting the retrieved flight as the current active flight in FlightController
      • Adding the associated booking to the flight's booking collection
      • Establishing complete context for luggage recovery workflows

      This context establishment is essential for luggage recovery operations that require access to complete flight and booking information. It enables administrative interfaces to display relevant flight details, passenger information, and booking context when processing lost luggage recovery requests.

      The method uses the luggage index to identify the specific lost luggage item from the search results maintained by LuggageController. This ensures that the correct flight context is established for the luggage item being processed.

      Integration with the flight management system ensures that flight context is properly established with complete flight information including schedules, capacity, status, and operational details needed for effective luggage recovery.

      The method is typically called when administrators or customer service representatives select a specific lost luggage item for processing, enabling the system to provide comprehensive context information for effective luggage recovery operations.

      Parameters:
      luggageIndex - the zero-based index of the lost luggage item in the search results

    • getAllForAFlight

      public void getAllForAFlight(Integer index)
      Retrieves comprehensive flight information including all associated bookings, passengers, and luggage.

      This method performs a comprehensive database operation to fetch complete information about a specific flight including all associated bookings, passengers, tickets, and luggage items. It provides a complete view of flight operations including passenger manifests, booking details, luggage tracking, and customer information for administrative and operational purposes.

      The operation involves multiple complex processes:

      • Database query through FlightDAOImpl to retrieve all flight-related data
      • Gate assignment retrieval and flight context establishment
      • Customer information processing for all flight passengers
      • Complete booking object construction with passenger associations
      • Ticket object creation with proper booking and passenger relationships
      • Luggage object creation with status and type information
      • Search result population across multiple controllers for comprehensive data access

      Flight context establishment includes setting the selected flight as the current active flight and retrieving gate assignment information if available. Gate information is used for operational planning and passenger information displays.

      Customer processing includes creating Customer objects for all passengers associated with the flight, enabling comprehensive passenger management and customer service operations. Customer information is deduplicated to prevent redundant entries while maintaining proper booking associations.

      Booking processing includes complete Booking object construction with proper customer and flight associations. Bookings are organized to support administrative operations including passenger manifests, check-in procedures, and operational reporting.

      Ticket processing includes creating Ticket objects with complete passenger information and proper booking associations. Both primary tickets (first ticket in each booking) and additional tickets are handled to ensure complete passenger representation.

      Luggage processing handles both typed luggage (with specific LuggageType) and untyped luggage items, ensuring that all luggage associated with the flight is properly represented with current status information for baggage handling operations.

      Data deduplication logic prevents duplicate entries across customers, bookings, tickets, and passengers while maintaining proper relationships between all entities. This ensures data consistency and prevents display issues in administrative interfaces.

      The method populates search results across multiple specialized controllers and integrates all data into the flight object's collections, providing both controller-based access for GUI components and flight-based access for business logic operations.

      Error handling includes comprehensive exception catching with user-friendly error messages displayed through FloatingMessage components using the error button reference. Database connectivity issues and data processing errors are handled gracefully with appropriate user feedback and detailed logging.

      The method is typically called when administrators need comprehensive flight information for operational management, passenger services, check-in procedures, or administrative reporting purposes.

      Parameters:
      index - the zero-based index of the flight in the search results to retrieve comprehensive data for

    • getAllLuggagesForABooking

      public void getAllLuggagesForABooking(Integer index)
      Retrieves comprehensive luggage information for a specific booking.

      This method performs a specialized database operation to fetch complete luggage information for all luggage items associated with a specific booking. It provides detailed luggage data including identification, type, status, and ticket associations for customer service operations and booking management purposes.

      The operation involves several key processes:

      • Flight context establishment based on the selected booking's flight
      • Booking selection for focused luggage operations
      • Database query through LuggageDAOImpl to retrieve booking-specific luggage
      • Luggage object creation with proper type and status information
      • Ticket-luggage association establishment for tracking purposes
      • Search result population for administrative access

      Flight context establishment sets the flight associated with the selected booking as the current active flight context, enabling flight-specific operations and providing necessary context for luggage management workflows.

      Booking selection establishes the specific booking context for luggage operations, ensuring that subsequent luggage management operations are properly scoped to the selected booking.

      Luggage processing handles both typed luggage (with specific LuggageType) and untyped luggage items, ensuring that all luggage associated with the booking is properly represented regardless of the completeness of the original luggage information. Each luggage item includes current status information for operational decision-making.

      Ticket-luggage associations are established by linking each luggage item to its corresponding ticket through ticket number correlation. This enables comprehensive luggage tracking and ensures that luggage items can be properly associated with their passengers.

      The method populates search results in LuggageController to enable administrative interfaces to access and manage booking-specific luggage information. Database IDs are also maintained for efficient luggage selection and operation targeting in administrative workflows.

      Error handling includes comprehensive exception catching with user-friendly error messages displayed through FloatingMessage components using the error button reference. Database connectivity issues and data processing errors are handled gracefully with appropriate user feedback and detailed logging for operational oversight.

      The method is typically called when administrators or customer service representatives need to view or manage luggage associated with a specific booking, enabling focused luggage operations within the booking context.

      Parameters:
      index - the zero-based index of the booking in the search results to retrieve luggage information for

    • getLogger

      public static Logger getLogger()
      Retrieves the centralized logger instance for system-wide logging operations.

      This static method provides access to the centralized Logger instance that is used throughout the airport management system for consistent logging operations. The logger is configured with the Controller class name to provide clear identification of log sources.

      The logger supports comprehensive logging capabilities including:

      • Error logging for exception handling and troubleshooting
      • Operational logging for system monitoring and audit trails
      • Debug logging for development and maintenance purposes
      • Performance logging for system optimization

      Logging levels are used consistently throughout the system to categorize log messages by severity and importance, enabling effective filtering and monitoring of system operations.

      The centralized logging approach ensures that all system components use consistent logging practices and that log messages are properly formatted and categorized for operational monitoring and debugging purposes.

      Integration with standard Java logging frameworks enables compatibility with existing logging infrastructure and supports various logging outputs including files, console, and external monitoring systems.

      The method is typically called by other system components that need to perform logging operations, ensuring that all logging is centralized and consistent across the entire airport management system.

      Returns:
      the centralized Logger instance for system-wide logging operations

    • updateUser

      public boolean updateUser(String mail, String username, String hashedPassword, JButton button)
      Updates user profile information with comprehensive validation and type-appropriate database operations.

      This method handles user profile updates for both administrators and customers by validating input data, determining user type, and coordinating with appropriate DAO implementations to persist the changes. It provides comprehensive validation feedback and maintains session consistency across all user controllers.

      The update process includes several key operations:

      • Input validation for email format and username format constraints
      • User type determination based on current session information
      • Type-appropriate database update operations through specialized DAOs
      • Session state synchronization across multiple controllers
      • User feedback through floating message components

      Input validation follows the same rigorous standards as user registration, using methods from UserController to ensure data consistency and system integrity. Email validation includes format checking and length constraints, while username validation enforces format rules and character restrictions.

      User type determination uses runtime type checking on the current logged user to select the appropriate update strategy. Administrators and customers have different update requirements and constraints:

      • Administrator Updates: Username and password only (email is immutable for admins)
      • Customer Updates: Email, username, and password (full profile flexibility)

      Database operations are performed through type-specific DAO implementations (AdminDAOImpl or CustomerDAOImpl) to ensure that updates are applied using the correct database schema and business rules for each user type.

      Session state synchronization ensures that all controllers (AdminController, CustomerController, UserController) maintain consistent user information after successful updates. This prevents inconsistencies between different system components that rely on user session data.

      User feedback includes specific validation error messages for input problems and success messages for completed updates. Database operation failures are handled gracefully with appropriate error messages for troubleshooting.

      Security considerations include maintaining password hashing and ensuring that user authentication state remains valid after profile updates. The method preserves existing security measures while enabling profile flexibility.

      The method is typically called from user profile management interfaces where users can modify their account information, enabling self-service profile management within appropriate security constraints.

      Parameters:
      mail - the updated email address for the user (used only for customer accounts)
      username - the updated username for the user
      hashedPassword - the updated pre-hashed password for the user
      button - UI button reference for displaying feedback messages
      Returns:
      true if the profile update was successful, false if validation failed or database errors occurred
